body:
Thanks for your thoughts @josevalim.  My thoughts about the benefits of extracting it as a gem are [also above](https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/11148#issuecomment-20191610), but basically 

1. There is a demonstrated desire for the gem as evidenced by forks of it popping up periodically
2. Statistics code really doesn't need to be tied to the Rails release cycle
3. Statistics LOC / code profiling aren't really a fundamental part of the Rails stack.
4. It's a common pattern for Rails to spawn dependent gems that don't themselves require Rails, or that aren't a fundamental part of the stack.
5. The code would be much better maintained on its own.  There's been some code rot around this functionality.

@dhh actually commented above [that he'd prefer to keep existing functionality intact](https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/11148#issuecomment-20754056) (at least per my understanding).

[related post on rubyonrails-core](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/rubyonrails-core/yVMreNOn2jQ/fCETsMyemn0J) if that is helpful for discussion.
